# News comment title:
No, Ron Paul Doesn't Deserve Any More Attention

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
14% polling nationally in recent polls. thats a small base alright. Paul surely has a higher approval rating that our fine example of a president.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I am a progressive. I love Mother Jones. But this is rubbish. Ron Paul just got 28% in the straw poll. Considering how divided our country is, and how third parties are meaningless, that 28% of Republicans can be thought of as 14% of the general electorate. He is not given enough airtime just like Dennis Kucinich and Ralph Nader are ignored when they run for president. You're letting your political beliefs get in the way of your judgment. And as far as that goes, Ron Paul's foreign policy would be much closer to a progressive foreign policy than four more years of Obama. Fact.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Apparently I have had the "wrong" impression about Mother Jones journalists / journalism. Certainly KD does not appear to fit. Ron Paul receiving no media attention IS a media story _ IF there is a free press STILL out there !

Ron Paul's issues _ well take your position _ IF you TRULY look at every candidate and how the speak and act on these issues _ PLEASE _ some one _ point out a candidate BETTER suited to CHANGE for the GOOD how our government has been Corrupted (Corporate-d).

I campaigned for Obama, and have voted for Independents, Republicans and was born in to a family that had campaigned, vigorously for Nixon ... which led us to seriously question numerous "beliefs" that we all had.

I hope Mother Jones is still part of the FREE press ... without which we will have to CREATE a new one on the backs / comment pages of these RIDICULOUSLY slanted / ignorant articles.

JF

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Quote of the Century: Mitt Romney on the Middle Class

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
... and this guy's supposed to be the best of the lot? Says a lot about the lot and not much about Romney. This almost makes one miss H. Ross Perot. Next?

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
 Ron Paul holds a lot of interesting positions. 

1) He is probably the most anti-war candidate from either party at the moment. 

2) He is also willing to point out some of the hypocrisy within the Republican Party. 

3) Ron Paul is also a crazy goldbug who does not understand the first thing about either monetary or fiscal policy. It isn't what he doesn't know that is the issue but what he thinks he knows. 

4) Then there is the long history of racist postings on his newsletter. "I don't control the content of the newsletter I publish" is a very strange defense. 

Yup, lots and lots of interesting positions. 

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Mitt Romney IS the Muppet Puppet talking corporate puppet !


>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Nobel Winners Call on Obama to Reject Keystone XL

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
This is BO's fork in the road, he can choose the path that will earns him the respect of the majority or he can choose to be another corporate stooge.

With increased frequency of natural disasters due to climate change more and more people will understand the serious problems facing future generations because of the greed and ignorance of the baby boomer generation.

Baby boomers are the worst generation in modern human history.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I don't know what show you had a "front row seat" for, but it sure wasn't the Reagan years.  Baby boomers led the resistance to Reaganism including Reagan's terrorist wars in Central America, Reagan's military buildup, Reagan's attempt to destroy the EPA and on and on.  And baby boomers led the resistance to Nixon and Johnson and Vietnam before that.  And baby boomers led the original environmental movement.  And the civil rights movement.

Sure, there were a whole lot of "selfish imbeciles" in the Baby Boom Generation -- because there were a whole lot of baby boomers.  (That's what the "boom" part means.)   But if you think there were a higher percentage of "imbeciles" in the Baby Boom Generation than in any other generation, you need to study some history.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


1966 ... we share that ... You know a "bunch of Boomers" ?

Those I know care - and this is true of virtually everyone - cares ultimately - most @ their own selves.
The true costs of living - very few individuals associate with public policy decisions that cost everyone more or less - as long as these individuals are making it.There are just more Boomers than other "groups" ... sad ...  that generation has the knowledge /power.So,I hear you ... and I'd like to hear more @ your electric drive Jeep ... I have a diesel Jetta ... saving about half ... and soon more when I'm running strictly on vegetable / plant oil.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Obama's Big Speech Doesn't Matter

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
In 2004, Washington attempted to create jobs for Americans by allowing American corporations to repatriate their profits by promising that the tax rate on these profits would drop from 35 percent to 5.25 percent as long as the funds were used for domestic investment with the ultimate goal of creating jobs.

As shown in this article, of the $312 billion in profits that were repatriated, between 60 and 92 percent of the funds were used to buyback shares, further enriching shareholders and executives:

http://viableopposition.blogspot.com/2011/08/americas-corporate-tax-holiday-2004.html

One certainly has to question the ability of legislators in Washington to create jobs….except for themselves.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Demand creates jobs. Create jobs/demand by a ten trillion dollar WPA type jobs program to rebuild our infrastructure. Hell, yes, that's socialism and it's what is needed now. Pay for this by raising taxes on the wealthy and getting the hell out of these absurd wars. Tepid and timid will not get er done.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


... and how sad that this is only too true.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Really... most small business owners make more than a million dollars? In what world?
Sad to think that he assumes the majority of people are really that stupid.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Conclusion

Replacing the current income tax system with a com- prehensive consumption-based tax might be expected to increase economic efficiency for a number of rea- sons. First, the switch to a consumption base would eliminate the influence of taxes on the timing of con- sumption. Second, the new system might treat different sources or uses of income more uniformly by including more of them in the tax base and subjecting all of them to similar tax rates. Third, a broader base would allow lower overall marginal tax rates, thereby reducing the amount by which taxes affect relative prices and hence all kinds of economic decisions. Society must put up with taxes if it desires government-provided goods and services. But the less the tax system influences the choices that consumers and businesses make, the more efficient that system will be, and the better off society will be.

The Middle Class Really Is in a Three-Decade Slump

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Thanks for the head's up. By sheer coincidence, I published the similar trends for individual income at http://middleclasspoliticaleconomist.blogspot.com/2012/03/basics-real-wages-remain-below-their.html 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Yes, let's tug our forelocks very hard and wonder, "How in the world this could possibly have happened?"

Note: the cleavage begins right at the 1980 election. Right about the time we saw massive decreases in top marginal tax rates, at the same time that politics swung hard right. Deregulation became a constant drumbeat. "Get the government off our backs," (translation - stop using government power to counteract the power of the rich). The overarching political philosophy became unashamedly grasping and contemptuous of anyone uncynical enough to believe it was about anything other than coddling the powerful and screwing everyone else. In a word, class warfare unleashed, with the middle class as the target.

It's taken a while , but by now even the Soma-addled masses are starting to notice. As money and power have accumulated at the top, the incongruities and stress on the 99% are impossible to hide, while the naked power of the rich (the unstoppable 2008 bailouts, HAMP's bald purpose to save the banks at the expense of everyone else, the inevitable presidential nomination of an equity kleptocrat on the GOP side) increasingly shows through.

Kevin is too polite to put it as coarsely as I'm doing here, but honestly, why are we pretending it's a conundrum? It really isn't.

# News comment title:
Did Jesus Exist?

It was not created from whole cloth.  It was created out of the messiah mythology of the Old Testament, specifically Isaiah.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
(a) You left something out in your summary above...
Bart Ehrman is a well-respected scholar who spent most of his life as a fairly zealous Christian until he decided, a few years ago, that he just couldn't go on --- the whole Christian story, old and new testament, was just too riddled with holes. (The particular issue that drove him over the edge was that of theodicy). So when Bart Ehrman explains that "vast majority of professional accept that a man named Jesus walked the streets of Roman Palestine." he is validating precisely that --- some guy named Jesus walked about Roman Palestine, probably got involved with the authorities, probably got crucified. He's not validating anything more --- born of a virgin, performed miracles, raised on the third day, etc etc.

(b) "does it really matter so much if he’s based on a historical person? Why does this evoke such strong feelings, and such acrimonious arguments, from atheists?"

Andrew Sullivan is, as far as I know, the only one who is claiming this evokes strong feelings and acrimonious argument. I know plenty of atheists and none of them have a problem with the historical claim that some guy named Jesus walked about Roman Palestine, just like they have no problem with the claim that some guy named Mohammed walked about Arabia, that some guy named Joseph Smith walked around upstate New York, and that some guy named L Ron Hubbard walked around the streets of Washington DC.

Finally the truth strikes back: 
I heard Barton, on the radio, lying about Jefferson just last month. 

There is more to gain here than the religious "right" mangle and manipulate the truth.
Read below for relevance: 1 of Jeff's top 3 achievements, the Va. Statute for Religious Freedom

Barton cites Jefferson's Bible incorrectly - but more so, Jefferson nearly kept that private while Barton ignores one of his proudest achievements: The Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom,
which reveals from this author of the Declaration of Independence, (his) views on people's rights, changing laws, and ultimately our right to our private relationship with religion.

* * * Of all of Jefferson's accomplishments, he assigned three to his self-designed Epitaph: * * *

(Near the end of his life, probably when he prepared and signed his final will in March 1826, Thomas Jefferson designed his own gravestone and prepared the text to be engraved on it. )
Here was buried Thomas Jefferson: Author of the Declaration of American Independence Of the Statute of Virginia for religious freedom & Father of the University of Virginia.


* * * Please follow the link or read, below, the Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom * * *

http://www.vahistorical.org/sva2003/vsrf.htm


I. Whereas Almighty God hath created the mind free; that all attempts to influence it by temporal punishment or burthens, or by civil incapacitations, tend only to beget habits of hypocrisy and meanness, and are a departure from the plan of the Holy author of our religion, who being Lord both of body and mind, yet chose not to propagate it by coercions on either, as was his Almighty power to do . . .

The second paragraph is the act itself, which states that no person can be compelled to attend any church or support it with his taxes. It says that an individual is free to worship as he pleases with no discrimination.

II. Be it enacted by the General Assembly, that no man shall be compelled to frequent or support any religious worship, place, or ministry whatsoever, nor shall be enforced, restrained, molested, or burthened in his body or goods, nor shall otherwise suffer on account of his religious opinions or belief; but that all men shall be free to profess, and by argument to maintain, their opinion in matters of religion, and that the same shall in no wise diminish, enlarge, or affect their civil capacities.

The third paragraph reflects Jefferson's belief in the people's right, through their elected assemblies, to change any law. Here, Jefferson states that this statute is not irrevocable because no law is (not even the Constitution). 

Future assemblies that choose to repeal or circumscribe the act do so at their own peril, because this is "an infringement of natural right." Thus, Jefferson articulates his philosophy of both natural right and the sovereignty of the people.

III. And though we well know that this assembly elected by the people for the ordinary purposes of legislation only, have no power to restrain the act of succeeding assemblies, constituted with powers equal to our own, and that therefore to declare this act to be irrevocable would be of no effect in law; yet we are free to declare, and do declare, that the rights hereby asserted are of the natural rights of mankind, and that if any act shall be hereafter passed to repeal the present, or to narrow its operation, such as would be an infringement of natural right.

# News comment title:
If You Want to Regulate Guns, Talk About Guns. Period.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
over the course of several conversations at samefacts.com with an interlocutor who kept insisting that knives and hammers were just as much a problem as guns i gathered the following  information from the national violent death reporting system for the years 2005-2009. i filtered out all violent deaths except those due to homicide, to suicide, or to homicide followed by suicide to restrict my search to intentional killings. the percentage of intentional killings in each of those years which were due to firearms, due to sharp instruments, and due to blunt objects–
2005:
firearm–57.4%
sharp–5.8%
blunt–3.5%

2006:
firearm–56.2%
sharp–6.0%
blunt–3.2%

2007:
firearm–55.9%
sharp–5.6%
blunt–3.5%

2008:
firearm–55.8%
sharp–6.0%
blunt–3.4%

2009:
firearms–55.8%
sharp–5.1%
blunt–3.2%with 5 year averages of:
firearms–56.2%
sharp–5.8%
blunt–3.4%indicating that over that five year period one would be 16.5 times more likely to be intentionally killed by a firearm than intentionally beaten to death, 9.7 times as likely to be intentionally killed by a firearm than to be intentionally stabbed or cut to death, and 1.3 times more likely to be killed with a firearm to be intentionally killed by all other means put together.perhaps this might be a useful start to talk about the problem of gun violence in the u.s. instead of the ravings of mr. lapierre.

# News comment title:
The GOP's Plan to Rig the Electoral College, Explained

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
This reminds me of Oklahoma's old "one county one vote" system, modeled after the U S Senate in which all states have equal votes.  This, too, favored low-population, rural counties, since 2,000 farmers could have the same clout as 200,000 voters in Tulsa.  Eventually the Supreme Court said it was OK at the federal level, but not at state.   Normally, the courts would be our hope here, ruling gerrymandering illegal.  But we've let Republicans appoint judges and justices too long (Reagan and two Bushes) and the opposition has blocked many good appointees Clinton and Obama wanted to put in.  So where lies our hope?  Never vote for a Republican again, for any office, ever.  Even so, 2020 will be too late for the 2016 and 2020 elections.

# News comment title:
It's a Virtual Currency! It's an Old-Fashioned Marketing Campaign! It's Both!

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Of course frequent flier miles are virtual currencies.  Moreover, they've been subject to quite a bit of money printing (100,000 free miles when you join!) and attendant inflation (a free flight is 20,000, no, I mean 25,000, no, I mean... miles).  They're even subject to a short-run Phillips curve (free miles when you join! was a big deal about 15 years ago and I remember a lot of people switching credit cards etc. to get miles), and long-run rational expectations (now it seems people just take for granted that the airlines are going to welch on mile redemption and don't bother so much). In an attempt to cut inflation despite the money printing, the airlines resorted to rationing and price controls ("ok, we're not changing the number of miles you need for a flight, but only if you fly on one of the following 6 days of the year").  

I think if anything the airlines are as good a demonstration of monetary theory as Krugman's famous baby-sitting co-op.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Oooh, oooh, Kevin. Pick me!

In keeping with Suzanne Mettler's arguments in The Submerged State, the American government has decided to operate a great deal of government economic and social programs as tax expenditures and various forms of tax breaks. At this point, we can take the exits for the unpopular tax deductions, like those for oil companies, yacht owners, and those with second mansions. Also the carried interest loophole.

BUT ... in accordance with Saez and Piketty's work positing 50-70% as the optimal top marginal tax rate, we should probably consider the current top level of around 40% as a massive tax break to the rich. Yes, we ought to recognize that taxes probably would be higher for the middle class in exchange for more and better quality public goods (like urban transportation systems and reliable universal health care), but the fact that raising taxes on the rich is still popular ought to be some indication that, well, actually the huge implicit social program the US government runs wherein it lets vast* classes of rich people privatize the gains and socialize the losses is actually pretty unpopular. In fact, most people would like for this program to be trimmed once and for all. Or, you know, once and again, as necessary, until they come to consensus on cutting, say, foreign aid.

For those whose knives are sharp … for those with dull tools … get a new edge, first:

"But if the problem is more people, then the answer, really, is higher taxes, lower benefits, more debt or some combination of the three."
More elderly ( receiving more benefits ) = more tax = more debt.

( Lower ? ) Let's not overlook more effective benefits.
The Free Market Twins, Greed and Avarice, have had their day. 

In the spirit of the Vernal Equinox, how 'bout some environmental thus demographically equal distribution  of our vast resources ? 

Personally, my family - due to a plane accident - despite three tiers of health insurance and a life insurance policy - distributed > $400,000 into the Thomas Jefferson Teaching Hospital in Philadelphia, after initially contributing to Wheeling, WV's local hospital, at the scene of the initial accident, not the scene of the subsequent crimes. I believe our family ought now be "shareholders" in the hospital and my vote is no more $600 / day pillows - $1,200 mattresses - $350 shampoos that somehow the nurses never even administered, as it took me, on my lunch break, walking the length of Walnut Street, to shampoo my mother's hair and rotate and dry her body so she could recover from the bed sores the hospital allowed my brilliant, licensed RN and recently degreed Sociologist with a degree in Public Administration and ER volunteer, allowed my mother to suffer some of the worst care despite active family participation and personal connections with and to many of the top doctors and administrators in that hospital ? 

No one at that hospital could ever explain or justify the vast array of different sized, colored, dated invoices for care and my dear mother decided to simply pay these bills when she was able to leave the hospital and take over the responsibility of settling these affairs - whereas - I saw the insurance companies and hospital and doctors as literally exaggerating and falsifying the majority of those bills. 

There are more effective ways to deliver health care benefits to the elderly and the injured.

We don't need Lower Benefits, we need better benefit at a more effective or fair and reasonable rates.

Look, I lived with a vegan - vegetarian for three years and our diets conformed naturally.

She insisted that I continue to eat small to moderate amounts ( yes, I caught my own fish ) of meat due to my blood type, O+  Honestly I did go, without suffering, days without meat, including no eggs, and I yet I noticed changes in my energy and attention, which did suffer a bit.

I aim to be as attentive to be body as possible and I rarely need, if ever, to see a doctor, I've seen two in the last decade, in fact, not counting a car accident that sent me to the emergency room.

* * * 

I am far from brainwashed. I biked 4,200 miles across country one summer. I ate far less meat than usual and still biked 75-100 miles / day. As a reward at Flathead Lake, Montana, by partner and I bought and grilled a steak and had a beer, as we found an abandoned grill on the beach by the lake where we camped overnight.

The following morning I was 'hungover' and not from a beer or two, I am certain that it was the steak, as I hadn't had any for several weeks and had suddenly consumed > 8-12 oz in one night. I was barely able to ride for the first 2 hours of the day so we hung out and waited it out.

I believe that you would get further sharing personal stories of health and vitality over judgements about carnivores, abuse, slaughter and brainwashing. Most of us are familiar with the Jungle and modern big agriculture, here.

Certainly many folks are not aware nor attentive to their options let alone their belief systems which govern their thoughts and actions. I believe that life is sacred, our bodies and when we choose and what we choose to put in on and around them should follow that level of care and consideration.

Pay-play that forward.

I'm not saying I'm smarter than anyone (well, obvious Shooter/Patty caveats apply, sigh...) but I have more than a little experience in metadata design and management, data mining, search & browse technologies, etc., and from that vantage point your conclusion is, if anything, too kind. Snowden did nothing revelatory as the existence of these programs was at best an open secret as far back as 2006 when the NYT ran its "Warrantless Wiretapping" expose. That particular program was quickly shut down, but following the discussion at the time it was pretty clear the NSA was using the 1979 SCOTUS decision that metadata gathering isn't an unreasonable search to Hoover up (I still laugh at the ironic pun!) massive amounts of information.  I've taken a lot of "friendly fire" over this issue in this space, but will say once again: (1) there is no "news" in what Snowden has released given what has been covered in the press over the last 5-8 years. (2) The actual danger to civil liberties, based on what I've seen thus far, is pretty minimal as the very amount of metadata that's being gathered itself makes abuse less likely. (3) That being said, the lack of transparency by the government around these programs is disturbing and serves as fertilized potting soil for the tin-foil-hat-crowd. (4) At least so far, my conclusion remains this is just another "throw money at anything associated with national security" boondoggle left over from the paranoid Cheney Bush administration that Obama is too cowardly to rein in lest he be called out as "weak on defending America." (Someone should ask Osama which president he found more impotent on the subject...) >>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<< I have checked all the original sources ( Snowden and Greenwald quotes ). I never see the word 'destroy'. The strongest word I see is a phrase 'could be harmful'. * * * Many good points made in this commentary ( TLM amplified: All about $$$ ) and yet the primary attention, here, is sniping at Greenwald and Snowden. That is misdirected energy. # News comment title:
Let My Papers Go!

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
We paid for the research, perhaps, but we didn't pay for the editing and archiving of the data and all the related infrastructure. There is no way to make it free.
That being said, I strongly support an open-access, pay-to-publish model, and would love to see taxes (including my own) raised to generate the $10-20 billion that it would take to buy out all the current publishers and release their archives. After that, we could maintain their structure, but allow anyone to read any of their articles forevermore. I am sure this would generate far more value than the vast majority of the tens of billions of dollars we spend on research every year.

Exchange saw purchases of 4,744 put options on United Airlines, but only 396 call options. Assuming that 4,000

these "insiders" would have profited by almost $5 million.

- On September 10, 4,516 put options on American Airlines were bought on the Chicago exchange, 
compared to only 748 calls. Again, there was no news at that point to justify this imbalance; 
Again, assuming that 4,000 of these options trades represent "insiders", they would 
represent a gain of about $4 million.

- The levels of put options purchased above were more than six times higher than normal.

- No similar trading 
in other airlines occurred on the Chicago exchange in the days immediately preceding Black Tuesday.

-
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co., which occupied 22 floors of the World Trade Center, saw 2,157 of its 
October $45 put options bought in the three trading days before Black Tuesday; this compares to an average of 
27 contracts per day before September 6. Morgan Stanley's share price fell from $48.90 to $42.50 in 
the aftermath of the attacks. Assuming that 2,000 of these options contracts were 
bought based upon knowledge of the approaching attacks, their purchasers could have profited by at least $1.2 
million.

- Merrill Lynch & Co., which 
occupied 22 floors of the World Trade Center, saw 12,215 October $45 put options bought in the four trading 
days before the attacks; the previous average volume in those shares had been 252 contracts per day [a 1200% 
increase!]. When trading resumed, Merrill's shares fell from $46.88 to $41.50; 
assuming that 11,000 option contracts were bought by "insiders", their profit would 
have been about $5.5 million.

Clinton Embraces Sanders' Message After Big New Hampshire Loss

# Oldest comment (from the thread):

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Um, Sanders may just be for real. What an interesting race so far. 

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Bernie Sanders Wins Every Demographic Group		

Senator Bernie Sanders beat Hillary Clinton among nearly every demographic group in the Democratic New Hampshire primary, according to exit polls. 

He carried majorities of both men and women. He won among those with and without college degrees. He won among gun owners and non-gun owners. He beat Mrs. Clinton among previous primary voters and those participating for the first time. And he ran ahead among both moderates and liberals.

Even so, there were a few silver linings for Mrs. Clinton. While Mr. Sanders bested her among all age groups younger than 45, the two candidates polled evenly among voters aged 45 to 64. And Mrs. Clinton won the support of voters 65 and older. And, though Mrs. Clinton lost nearly every income group, she did carry voters in families earning over $200,000 per year.

David R. Jones of Baruch College is a Times consultant.

“If you want to stump a Democrat, ask 
them to name an accomplishment of Hillary Clinton,” 
quipped at Wednesday’s Republican debate. The line got hearty 
applause—but it also cut to the core of one of the defining lines of 
attacks against the former first lady and Democratic presidential 
frontrunner. After nearly forty years in public life, what exactly has 
she accomplished? 

It’s a question that even, at times, has tripped up Clinton herself: 
During her 2014 book tour, when ABC’s Diane Sawyer asked her about her “marquee achievement,” Clinton changed the subject and she fumbled over a similar question during a women’s forum in Manhattan last year. I see my role as secretary—in fact leadership in general in a democracy—as a relay race. You run the best race you can run, you hand off the baton. Some of what hasn’t been finished may go on to be finished,” she told Thomas Friedman. “I’m very proud of the [economic] stabilization and the really solid leadership that the administration provided that I think now leads us to be able to deal with problems like Ukraine because we’re not so worried about a massive collapse in Europe.”

The question Fiorina posed has also tripped up members of the Obama administration. When State Department spokesperson Jen Psaki was asked last year to “identify one tangible achievement” accomplished through one of Hillary Clinton’s key projects as Secretary of State—the first-ever audit of the department—Psaki punted, “I am certain that those who were here at the time, who worked hard on that effort, could point out one.”

Hillary’s supporters have been stumped too. When Bloomberg Politics’ Mark Halperin asked focus group of Iowans this summer about Hillary Clinton’s accomplishments, one Democratic supporter said, “I honestly can’t say I followed along [with] everything that was going on.”

# News comment title:
Donald Trump’s Job Approval Is Rock Steady

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I met with Larry Sabato, recently.

He posed an interesting question about the validity of polling, which has changed, significantly.
Polling used to be a face to face affair, then more by phone, now, more via digital interface.

In all of the above, there are a number of people who will answer the polls, a number who will not, and those who adjust their responses.

The interesting question: Has technology altered the number who answer, those who will not, and the number of adjustments ?

Have those who answer, changed ?

Policy by polling, when already only 40-60% vote and 100% are affected by policy...this situation suggests solutions such as Ranked Choice Voting and other incentives to register and share the 'true' issues on which US citizens - essentially - require their representatives to act.

# News comment title:
Was Civilization Just a Big Mistake?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
It's not civilization that was the problem, it was that we structured civilization around making the weak dependent on the powerful. Without civilization, we had resource conflicts that led to war and instability - to fix it, we gave individuals power to decide how those resources were used, and guards to enforce those rules, but they had no legal obligation to anyone but themselves. It wasn't the only option - we could have rationed our resources and created the rules around making sure everyone had equal access to them, and we could have avoided pretty much all of the biggest problems with civilization in the past. It's just that since civilization grew around those conflicts the path of least resistance was to have a strong ruler to keep everyone in line, which was reinforced as they sought to conquer others.

Civilization wasn't a mistake, but laws that inherently make some people dependent on others is a mistake, especially without laws that make people responsible for those that are dependent on them.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
When asked what he thought of Western civilization, Mahatma Gandhi said.... 'I think it would be a good idea.”

Jean-Jacques Rousseau said .......“Civilization is a hopeless race to discover remedies for the evils it produces.” 

And Orson Welles said.... “If there hadn't been women we'd still be squatting in a cave eating raw meat, because we made civilization in order to impress our girlfriends.”

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Those who enforce a singular version of Earth are the one's endangering those who would live a diversity of versions.

Might fine dancing, gepap.

>>> END COMMENT <<<
